Can you help me on this:Determine the volume of the solid generated by revolving the plane area bounded by the curve y^(2)=4x and x=4 about the line x=4.(Small Hint will work).Thanx For the reply btw.
i mention that in this tutorial briefly, you just have to make a couple adjustments and use the other variable but the concept is the same.

understand the intuition behind what it means to rotate and add up the sums of areas.we know that the cross sectional area is still circles, so it will be: y^2 = x rearranged. ( aka what value of x do i need the radius to be at a given value of y) so A = pi * (y^2  )^2 . and integrate this from 0 to any point of your  choosing on the y axis, with respect to y (dy) as you are adding cumulative volumes in the y plain. so.  v = integral 0 -> n  of pi * y^4    in general : find the value of the radius of the cross sectional areas in terms of y and integrate with respect to y
a torus is a three-dimensional surface of revolution! a washer is a two-dimensional cross section.

A torus is rounded on the edges. He was correct in calling it a washer because it is obtained by revolving a rectangle around 360 degrees.  Rectangles are straight, not round so the resulting 3d object is flat like a washer you would put on a nut and bolt.
